job_title: Front End Web Developer in Annapolis, MD
pros: Free tuition (minus fees) for most full-time employees! Its a priceless bonus that I am fully taking advantage of. Working with academics is a fantastic, rewarding experience, and having the space - and full support of management- to pursue further education and training is very welcomed, and definitely refreshing after my years spent in the private sector. Its a rare (and worthwhile) space to have your work based on quality, instead of profitability or extreme speed. You wont find a 3 time doctorate - especially one willing to help you improve your skills - in the average office, these people know what they're doing and you can learn so much just by being in the same room as them and working on projects together. I would definitely recommend finding a university position for anyone starting out in their career and who wants the support to improve their skills, continue training/education, and also gain mentors who are so beyond incredible and geniuses within their subjects. Its also a great space for work/life balance. The main goals are to learn, improve the world, and share knowledge, and I attribute these goals to the healthy/positive atmosphere and the type of people attracted to these positions. So far in my career within this environment I have had zero encounters with domineering people who are only interested in being in charge (which was a common occurrence for me in the business world), so it is easy to take your time off, work from home whenever, and just overall have a very healthy work/life balance without ever impacting your work or career. Working here has definitely made me appreciate work/life balance and healthier mental health, neither were freely given to me in the past but it is easy and quick to gain here. Not an environment for anyone who NEEDS to be told what to do, though, you need to know how to do the work and how to manage your own time and tasks. But if you can manage your work and time well, you can be very comfortable on the average day and have a great work/life balance. My entire time here I have worked from home, they are great about hybrid work and letting people decide how they work best. It creates teams that churn out projects quickly without working anyone to death, and I have yet to meet a stressed employee in my office (at least any employee who is not in management).
cons: Positions are usually based on grant money, so the salaries are on the lower end of industry averages and specific positions are rarely guaranteed for life, but you would never find this kind of flexibility, support, and education opportunities in the public sector. This is a great position for someone who wants to build their experience and prepare for the advanced years of their career, but I would not recommend it to someone who is there for the money and/or has no interest in quickly/vastly improving their skills or gaining experience with true industry experts. Also - to reiterate what I mentioned in the pros - this is not an environment for anyone who NEEDS to be told what to do, you definitely need to know how to do the work and how to manage your own time and tasks. But if you can manage your work and time well on your own, you can be very comfortable on the average day and have a great work/life balance.

If you are a slacker and want to cheat into the system, UMD is a perfect place for you. They will make sure to increase your pay just because your pay is lower than others. review_title: Great Environment With A Few Drawbacks
job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: UMD provides very good benefits for full-time employees, although I was working part-time for my most recent position. The environment is friendly and supportive, with a strong emphasis on diversity and encouraging students
cons: Like most large institutions, UMD is held back by bureaucratic hurdles. It is often a struggle to figure out what needs to be done, and you will need to be proactive in order to successfully get something done through the system. Even if you submit all the correct forms, if you do not follow up on a request it may become permanently stuck in the approval process (or simply discarded) without notice. Being able to rely on the University to take care of most details can also create a false sense of security; occasionally I would discover a crucial requirement at the last minute that the University simply did not notify me about, and I would need to scramble at the last minute. In addition, the compensation can be lower than equivalent positions at other universities.

job_title: Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: The pros is that you get to obtain your degree at any level for free, so does your spouse and children after working there for 2 years. Also, you start off with 22 vacation days, plus 3 personal days and 15 sick days so that is basically 5 weeks of vacation, plus you get the week of Christmas off bringing it to 6 weeks, and then you get an extra two days off for spring break. You won't work anywhere that offers that many days off regardless of your level of employment. You'd have to be a senior executive to get that much time off and you can't be free education. Also, you have the option to be part of their pension plan and after 10 years you are vested. Most companies don't even offer pension plans anymore.
cons: The cons are the systems are very antiquated. Many long-time employees are reluctant to embrace technology in order to do their jobs more efficiently. Also, the salary is very low. You have to decide if you want great benefits now but possibly struggle to make ends meet, or make more money somewhere with not so great benefits.

review_title: decent place to be a professor
job_title: Associate Professor in Washington, DC
pros: The benefits of tenure-track jobs (health insurance, retirement) are above many other state schools. Salaries are in line with other good state schools and decent private schools. The research faculty in many departments are very intelligent and research-active, but still put a strong emphasis on teaching quality
cons: Raises have been few and far between - there have been virtually no merit-based raises in the past decade. This disincentivizes publishing in top journals and going the extra mile. I'm sure it's not unique to UMD, but many of the administrative offices are either incompetent or too lazy to do their job. Some student-facing offices are downright rude to students. There are also numerous offices designed to perform a function (e.g., marketing, advising, career services) that seem to be unable to accomplish even their basic assigned function.

pros:
UMD has great benefits beyond health insurance, including lots of paid holidays and generous leave (especially for exempt positions), FSA, tuition remission for employees anywhere in the USM system and at UMD for employee's immediate family members, and more.

job_title: Assistant Director in College Park, MD
pros: IMPORTANT: I work in an administrative and support role, not in an academic role (a) Benefits are wonderful; (b) The people are mostly wonderful-It's a big place so there are always bad apples; (c) lots of young people and energy; (d) generally supportive, warm, and might I add - loving environment... but remember letter b, part 2; (e) somewhat transparent with shared governance through the University Senate; (f) comfortable - ultimately, it's a State Government job, so people get comfortable and simply don't leave!
cons:
(a) It's a State Government job, so people get comfortable and don't leave, when they should; (b) It's large with a culture of inefficiency which is frustrating for efficient, task-oriented, or ex-military people (c) professional pay must be negotiated up-front. (d)There is help, but you are generally on your own with your career path and your plan for professional growth - there are no paths or plans. I would argue that this is true everywhere, but see letter f in Pro's and letter a in Cons. (e) They struggle with diversity in senior positions.

Let me explain letter (e): Although Dr. Wallace D. Loh - the past president was Chinese and the current president, Dr. Darryll J. Pines is black, the campus - like the rest of the United States, has Black folks and Hispanics working at entry level and service jobs - house keepers, food service workers, etc... and White folks at the top - Deans, Directors, Department Heads, etc. Diversity is an aspired value but Maryland is a historically and predominately white institution (PWI). However, they are very supportive of LGBTQ staff in senior levels... but this isn't helping Black America; not really. Even so, if you are generally qualified/credentialed and know how to "play the game" in America as a Black or Hispanic American, Maryland can still be a fulfilling place to work, and you may even get a senior position!

review_title: Resident Director, a highly rewarding position with little chance for inter-institution advancement.
job_title: Resident Director in College Park, MD
pros: The University of Maryland is a diverse, fast-paced, enjoyable work environment. If offers a great opportunity to work and pursue higher education at the same time. The salaries offered are competitive with other large state school systems, and the benefits are comparable as well. Working in a residence hall you meet and interact with a cross-section of students, and you help them grow and develop throughout their first years in a college institution. Developing staffs of Resident Assistants and Community Managers is rewarding. Staff development is the highlight of the year, offering unique ways to develop and strengthen bonds with your co-workers and subordinates. The office tries hard to push for a family type feel, and for the most part, that permeates the workplace.
cons: Promotions are hard to come-by for moving up from the Resident Director position. You can be in this position for several years, and the ability to become a Assistant Director of Residential Education (The next step after Resident Director) is compromised by the long retention rates in that position, whereas the Resident Director position turns over every few years. The ability of upper management to strongly articulate greater University Policy is not strong at all. Resident Directors are often left out of the decision making process when it comes to policy. The job is also a work strong position. Your job is always placed higher then your personal life unless it comes to participating in the higher level academic programs, which is not required, but encouraged.

review_title: Beware extremely low salaries! Subject to more lay-offs and state furloughs! Not even COLAs!
job_title: Administrative Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Employees have access to great benefit like libraries, events, tuition remission for self and kids, and decent medical coverage.  Beautiful campus, easily accessible. Near major highways, metro train and bus routes.  Several restaurants in the area. Approx 15 mins from Washington DC. Excellent work life balance.  Enjoy working with my coworkers and students. Union for non-exempt staff. Most people stay because of the tuition benefits esp if they have children.  Good job for two-income household.
cons: Extremely low pay!!  If you are a single parent, don't have a degree, and don't negotiate a high salary during your interview, your doomed!  You will become a member of the "working poor" class.  I've been employed at the UMD for over six years and never received a raise, or COLA, only state furloughs which means I've lost money!  Subject to additional furloughs. The cost of parking increases and medical coverage increases each year. But salaries for non-exempt staff remain the same. Non exempt staff have no opportunities for advancement within current position/unit.  Must apply for jobs in other units if they choose to advance.  Doesn't seem to value non exempt employees or those without a college degree.

review_title: An invaluable life experience and a great setting for personal development.
job_title: Resident Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
University of Maryland in general and Department of Resident Life in particular is a very supportive, tolerant, accepting, engaging, and rewarding place to work.

I've learned as much from my job as I have from my classes. I've also found sincere care and support from my coworkers and supervisors (even three or four levels above me - people I'd hardly expect to remember my name).

The Department of Resident Life has a holistic approach to its mission and its staff. 

Opportunities for advancement for undergraduate employees are strongly dependent on the position one starts out with and the department one works for, but it is possible to hold several simultaneous positions in different departments.
cons:
Competition for the Resident Assistant position is very high due to a large number of applicants. 

By the nature of the position, promotion is not an option. Within the Department of Resident Life, there are limited opportunities for serving other paid positions (though plenty for unpaid ones). 

The training process, involving a class, EDCP470, and a two week-long on-the job training program of lectures, presentations, and activities from 8:00am to 8:00pm (with breaks) is quite tedious, though necessary and overall effective.

While most Resident Directors are very reasonable, supportive, and easy-going supervisors, a very small minority can be excessively demanding.

review_title: UMD needs to pay graduate assistants more!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
1) The engineering school and science departments at UMD are well-known so there are many good professors you can work with.
2) I like our campus overall.
3) I don't like the College Park area and it is not a good college town, but we are close to very good places like Washington DC, Bethesda, Alexandria, Tysons, Annapolis, ... so overall, the location is a plus.
cons:
1) At a lot of universities, the health insurance and extra fees are not deducted from your job offer salary and the insurance automatically comes with any graduate assistantship. UMD is not like that! We have to pay a mandatory fee each semester and insurance gets deducted from our bi-weekly pay.
2) The salary at some departments at UMD are NOT uniformly distributed over the year. In Fall and Spring, pay is extremely low compared to housing prices; I make around $700 bi-weekly after insurance, tax, and fees are deducted. In the summer, some profs offer full-time RAs to compensate for that, so if you don't get the full RA in the summer, you're doomed! Also, if you go back home or go to an internship in the summer, you'll miss out on the possibly full RA summer pay. 
3) The housing prices in College Park are high considering its proximity to the DC area, and the graduate assistant salary is not at all proportional to the housing prices over here.

review_title: UMD : An Exciting, cutting edge technological experience and learning
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant, Grade III in College Park, MD
pros:
There's a good research culture. Students and researchers intermingle and exchange ideas and thoughts in a free and constructive way. There's a lot of transparency in every level of communication and most faculty have an open door policy.

Apart from approachability there's also a lot of scope for interdisciplinary research (at least among the different engineering disciplines). Which makes archaic ideas like "aerospace engineers" deal with only rockets and planes quite redundant. Also, the classes that are offered are quite stimulating for most parts and very helpful in gaining expertise in one's area of research. The atmosphere is fairly laid back and not very high pressure.
cons:
Takes most people a long time to graduate, there should be more planning and cohesiveness in getting people graduated sooner.  Need better forums to bring research from different areas together, off late new initiatives are in place for graduate students to come and present their research to others. There need to be more panel meetings to meet all faculty and understand their work.

The department is split up into several labs in different parts of the campus. It would be more useful to have all units in close proximity to improve constructive interactions. Also, the facilities at the various labs while adequate, could use an upgrade in certain student facilities such as printers, computers etc.

job_title: IT Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: The atmosphere is relaxed and flexible, a good place for someone with family or health problems. There are a fair amount of opportunities for advancement and very nice benefits - in part due to a no fee union membership. One of the best benefits I'd recommend taking advantage of is tuition remission: 8 hours a semester and in the summer for the employee at any USM institution and full time remission for spouses and children without bachelors degrees at the University of Maryland itself.
cons:
While entry level pay is very nice do not expect the pay at advanced positions to equal the private sector. The benefits and flexibility may make up for that for some, but you will eventually end up making as little as half the private sector equivalent to a management level job.

Another potential downside is that if you end up in a unit or department with poor management there is very little hope in change. People very rarely get fired or removed so long as they don't break any laws or codes of conduct, regardless of their productivity.

review_title: Struggling at the moment, but planning for the future
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: It's a large, research-oriented university.  There's a lot going on, and there are many world-class scientists doing cutting-edge research.  It would require exceptional diligence to avoid learning about at least a few cool projects.  Regarding the university's recent problems, President Loh seems to understand them and has been taking steps to address them.
cons: Following the 2008 economic crisis, the State of Maryland actually tried to protect the University of Maryland.  UMD in turn tried to protect its research programs, at the cost of many mid- and low-level administrators.  In some very meaningful ways, the University of Maryland is actually a pretty okay place to be doing research right now.  In other meaningful ways however, the University of Maryland is a very annoying place to be doing anything right now because much of the administration has been gutted.  Many professors have resisted shouldering the extra work and have focused instead on deflecting the work onto whoever they can.  This is in part because the funding situation has become desperate and many of them can't afford to focus on anything other than securing their next grant.  I'm not sure how this compares to other institutions, but it hasn't been pleasant.

review_title: Good place to work, but hard not to get stuck
job_title: Unit Secretary in La Plata, MD
pros:
Benefits offered were great. 
Great work-life balance.
Lots of respect from management, or at least mine was great. 
Easy interview process.
Nice compensation for not being salary.  
Got a raise.
cons:
This may specifically apply to my job position: 

I'm not sure how I would be able to promote through the hospital with the position I had. It would take certifications/medical degrees I'm sure, which I was not interested in. 
My schedule was 3-11pm. This is okay, but not favorable.

job_title: Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: The University of Maryland has many research opportunities for physics Ph.D. students. Once they know you, the administration is very helpful and certainly works with students to take care of any paperwork. Student's I've worked with have had many opportunities after graduating. The graduate student community is also quite tight-knit and helpful.
cons: As with any top-tear research school, work can get a little overwhelming. This is really specific to a student's advisor, but the school definitely protects the tough advisors who bring in a lot of grant money. Grad student stipend is enough to get by but not much more.

review_title: This review is with respect strictly in UMD OIT, the IT department.
job_title: in College Park, MD
pros: University benefits are better than corporate (5 weeks vacation, paid 403b, free tuition) and pay rivals that of corporate IT in major cities.
cons: Upper management is brain dead, uninspired and highly risk adverse even for the higher ed. and government sector, both of which this company falls under. It is a state university and MD politicians pulled a week’s salary in 2008, 2009 and 2 more weeks are slated for 2010. More problematic is upper level management (CIO) not recognizing ineffective and cancerous mid management that often opts for decisions counter productive or even completely against the interest of the department and it’s constituents (faculty, students, external research groups). Moral is low; as promotion is null and work runs at a bucolic pace. This is where people look for a lifetime job and go to die. If you like money, a fast, energetic environment and ability to find successive positions; stick to corporate. State and federal government is dead and bloated.

job_title: Student Driver in College Park, MD
pros:
Paid CDL training and license, which is practically unheard of in other companies - the license itself is valued at over $2000, and all that is asked in return is one semester of work at an avg of 12hrs/week (unless things have changed in the past 2 years). Easy. 

There's no uniform, and you can clock in at different places on campus. Convenient.

I recommend working maintenance - those skills are invaluable if you plan on owning an automobile or bike.
cons:
Scheduling can be somewhat inflexible (don't you dare change your class schedule after shift pick), and seniority is everything - you may be stuck with some pretty terrible shifts your first semester. 

Never sign up for College Park Metro (104) or New Carrollton (126).  Trust me.

Shift pick was literally the most tedious thing I experienced in college, so I recommend signing up for the bare minimum 12hrs/week and picking up shifts for the extra cash. Don't let yourself get suckered into making any extra shifts permanent - you'll want that flexibility.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: I worked in McKeldin. I mostly unpacked and shelved books. It was kind of lonely but also nice alone time to listen to music or a podcast.
cons: I was asked to work the same hours during finals week which was unpractical. I was a freshman and this was my first job - every job on campus afterwards actually didn't even require me to come in during finals. I guess the fact that they need people managing the library during finals makes sense but as a full-time student, I found the lack of leniency unreasonable. Also, I was told you need two semesters experience before they let you work a the front desk (which is a chiller job, you can even do homework) but I saw people get directly hired to the front desk.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: It's great to be able to make a salary while going to school. Lots of research going on with lots of different fields within the department, and interdisciplinary research is encouraged.
cons:
Communication with advisors was an issue for me. This very much depends on the group you are in, but occasionally you can find yourself having multiple people to report to, that all work together in some capacity but don't communicate. Having to tell a supervisor "no" on behalf of another supervisor is really difficult, especially as a graduate student where you are constantly bouncing between being a legitimate researcher and being a student who is trying to learn.

For me personally, I found a lot of people I worked with to be pretty introverted, which can be expected being a lab researcher, but it meant working was very isolating since I was in a small group. Luckily I had a good network of friends and family around DC and Virginia, so most of my free time and social life was spent away from College Park.

review_title: Department of Resident Life at UMD
job_title: in College Park, MD
pros: It has a great liberal, large university atmosphere.  At a large school, every employee lives in a fishbowl, and thus, everyone is very respectful and kind.  It's also a great opportunity to make lasting friendships, since it is a very laidback atmosphere, depending on which department you work in.
cons: As with any large state university, there is tremendous red tape to getting anything done.  Processes and forms don't make sense, and you will be writing the same things five times over.  You will have several bosses, job duties aren't clearly delineated, and to get things done you have to rely on your employees stepping up and stepping up yourself as well, because there's a very "we're all in this together" attitude to compensate for the disorganization, or else nothing would get done.

job_title: Technical Team Lead, Athletics IT in College Park, MD
pros: Great benefits, they'll pay for you and your family to go to college. They pay upfront instead of reimbursement. Because it's in higher-education, the environment is all about learning, so they are supportive of people trying to branch out and discover where you want to go next.
cons: There are a lot of arbitrary rules regarding IT, and no one pays attention to half of them, which can get really frustrating when you work in IT. Many departments would prefer to get the dollar store solution, rather than spend a little more time and money to get the right solution, even if it would save money in the long run. The decision makers aren't leaders, they're managers with no vision, so it's very difficult to improve the business in any meaningful way.

review_title: Good benefits for a student job, wish contracts were longer

pros: For a part-time student job, the pay is very decent and the benefits are good - not many 20-something graduate students can secure health insurance, dental, etc for about $30 a month.
cons: The contracts are often ended abruptly without much notice. I have seen many colleagues be notified less than a month away from the end of their contract that their job won't be renewed, leaving them high and dry in terms of tuition payment and a salary.

review_title: Not all benefits can be quantified !!

review_title: 10 Yrs Employment + Education but No Room to Grow

job_title: Web Developer in Silver Spring, MD
pros:
* Good salary, excellent benefits (including health insurance, retirement, tuition remission, etc.).
* Excellent work/life balance.
* Extremely bright, sharp, intelligent coworkers.
* Some very interesting projects, and occasional glimpses of groundbreaking research and related thinking.
cons:
* No meaningful training opportunities; learning is on your own time and dime.
* No career path or opportunity to advance on team.  It's an academic institution, so without a masters degree, particularly in a relevant academic field, it can often be hard to be seen/heard, opportunities are limited, and it's almost impossible to advance to a management position.
* It's a state government institution, so salaries are okay, but raises are few and far between.
* With these qualifications, I would still recommend the university as a place to work -- just know the environment.

job_title: Accounting in College Park, MD
pros:
Union will represent on major issues on campus even if you're not a paying member
SNOW DAYS! Most of the time, anyway
State benefits
Interesting training and development opportunities
Work/Life balance - during the summer we can have flexible work arrangements
cons:
You have to pay for parking
Non-exempt employees must participate in a mandatory 7% pension deduction from paycheck
I felt like I was thrust into the position, having to figure things out on my own (may not be the case with every job like mine on campus)
Pay - horrible - unless you're an Assistant Director, Associate Director, or above

job_title: Private Consultant in Columbia, MD
pros: The University of Maryland offers you an opportunity not only to grow in your own position, but to seek out positions across the university system. Another main benefit is the tuition remission program which allows you to take classes towards your degree undergraduate or graduate for free.
cons: The downside of working at University of Maryland College Park is that it is difficult to get through the process of getting hired. It often takes months 2 go through all of the review steps by each University Department. If you are patient though, you can enjoy a very fruitful life.

review_title: A good place to get a PhD
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: I was a science graduate student, and received good mentorship. Most of the people that I knew in my program were very happy with their experience. Graduate student life is lots of work, but the pay at UMd is enough to live on (if you're careful) and the school isn't taking in more science students that it can afford to support to graduation (which is sometimes the case at Ivy League schools). There's good health insurance because you receive state employee benefits. I would recommend working as a graduate student at UMd.
cons: As is typical for graduate school, there were no official family leave or maternity leave policies. Traffic can be a mess, but that's not unusual for the DC area.

review_title: Innovative Research in a well funded University.
job_title: Lab Manager in College Park, MD
pros: The University of Maryland at College park was a great first place to work.  Coming directly out of an Undergraduate program at a different school, i was truly amazed of the campus.  The opportunities to take part in a great research program was outstanding.  The programs here are well funded and well supported by the senior leadership.  This commitment to excellence shows by the caliber of students and staff.  It was a pleasure to work there.
cons: The pay in the university are lower than what equivalent positions would command in private industry.  The campus is rather large, and can be difficult to get around, especially on the very hot and humid days in mid summer.

job_title: Professor in College Park, MD
pros: Maryland is clearly and conspicuously in the process of converting itself into a high-quality public University. It provides lots of opportunities for growth, and considerable academic freedom. If you are able to do the job that would be required at a prestige institution, Maryland will be thrilled with you and will treat you (reasonably) well.
cons: Chronically underfunded by an overly meddlesome state legislature, Maryland struggles constantly to maintain tolerable working conditions in one of the most expensive parts of the USA. The tuition is low, which is great for the undergraduates, but graduate students, faculty, and staff are all paid at rates that are not competitive with the Federal Government, regional industry, or other regional institutions.

job_title: Take A Big Guess!!!!! in Largo, MD
pros: The only good thing about work in "this department" is the coworkers your meet!  They will become long lasting friends!
cons: Management is incompetent , they rather hire externally and they really hire people that don't understand the lasting history of "this department".  Management is up right disrespectful and have no respect for staff.  You cant advance unless you're a certain "blank" and young and it's clearly depicted in "this department" upper management.  This group of employees apply for positions and never get interviews, you just feel stuck.  No cares and you're just treated like a piece of trash!  Stay away no benefits whats so ever!!!!

review_title: Decent Job but it will wear you down
job_title: in College Park, MD
pros:
* get state benefits
* plenty of time off
* good home / work balance
cons:
* it doesn't matter how hard you work or how well you perform because you get the same benefits as those that under perform.
* 2 years of mandatory furloughs, 3 years no pay raises
* too many long timers that don't understand how work can be done.  They only know the UMUC process.
* there is no sense of prioritization - everything is high priority
* the IT infrastructure is a weird.  It is either the best money can buy or the absolute worst.  There is no in between.  There is a multi-million dollar data center with the biggest and best hardware imaginable but one can't get virus software for their laptop.

review_title: Not the best or worst place to be a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Good medical benefits, strong graduate student government, campus activities and recreation, commitment to diversity, access to health and mental health resources, clear PhD graduation guidelines (even if a bit complicated)
cons: Lack of financial resources if funding is lost, little non-academic career guidance (depends on department), departments are run like independent states (so your mileage may vary) and sometimes refuse to share/charge fees to use resources, university suffers from administrative the bloat that is endemic of academia in this day and age

job_title: Unit Secretary in Baltimore, MD
pros: Their wonderful to work for.  It's alot to learn here.  Always room for growth.  It feels very rewarding to come to work everyday.  It's a diverse group of people from all over the world.  You have great managers and nurses that are team players always willing to help.
cons: Very  few cons.  Sometime the hours maybe long, but it doesn't even matter.  You want to be here.  At first I didn't like the long hours, but the people grew on me. I became to love them, they are   my family.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate/Fellow in College Park, MD
pros: While it depends department to department, the department I am in has excellent support staff who have are always ready to help. As a state university, the health benefits are excellent. My advisor  has been very accommodating with taking time off and working from home. The research environment is very collaborative and engaging. For a young researcher, there are plenty of opportunities to learn new skills and find new collaborations, including with scientists at the various national laboratories in the area.
cons: Some of the facilities and offices are quite old depending on the building you are working in. Having a professor as a manager can be frustrating as their attention can be split between a lot of different tasks (teaching, managing, researching, applying for grants) which can end up with none of these tasks being performed very well.

review_title: Many years, great relationships, sub-par compensation
job_title: General Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great university, good people, "fringe benefits" were great.  Constantly evolving work environment, endless growth opportunities.  Genuine family atmosphere within each department.
cons: Compensation not competitive with private sector, promotions/new hires can be very, very slow to take shape due to the University needing to comply with so many state regulations and fair hiring practices.  In theory it makes sense, in reality it isn't practical.  There's just an endless line of red tape that needs to be dealt with before anything can get done, whether from an HR standpoint, or even just a day to day management standpoint.

review_title: Lots of pluses, some real negatives
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Solomons, MD
pros: opportunities for exploring intellectual freedom and creativity
cons: Satellite campus is small (which can also be good), so opportunities for intellectual interaction with colleagues in your field are limited, and campus also suffers because it is saddled with the larger bureaucracy that it is a part of (UMCES).  Post docs are few, and are often forgotten as a group, though this may be a common situation. Oh yeah, get rid of the moniker  University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science Chesapeake Biological Laboratory...please.  88 characters is more than a little excessive.

review_title: College of Arts and Humanities: IT Web and Application Services: Great Experience, Great Pay & Benefits, Great Boss
job_title: Graduate Assistant IT Web Developer in College Park, MD
pros: Great Work Experience: Instead of coming out of my master's with no work experience I now have a year and a half of extremely valuable work experience. My boss is the greatest boss you can ask for, as she is mentoring me in a very successful way, she allows me to make my own schedule since she understands that there are classes involved and she treats me with a lot of respect. The salary is great and on top of it, I don't have to pay tuition (as a Graduate Assistant).
cons: None that I can think of, honestly, I've been working here for a year and a half and I've loved everything about this job.

review_title: A great place to do research, but you won't be part of the University community.
job_title: Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great scientific community, good interaction between disciplines and departments.  The large number of available research assistantships limits the amount of time a PhD student needs to focus on teaching instead of actual research and developing their PhD.
cons: The pay is low, even for an assistantship, and the graduate student community is respected and recognized very little by both the University as a whole and by select departments.  Even as a critical component to the University, the Graduate Study body is overlooked in regards to major decisions regarding the campus, facilities, etc.

review_title: Student trying to make ends meet
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant/Student Software Engineer in College Park, MD
pros: At both my jobs at Maryland, my employers are very understanding of how important schoolwork is. My hours are extremely flexible at my part time SE job and potentially minimal as a Teaching Assistant. My coworkers are great and I love both my jobs.
cons: Pay is underwhelming, I'm mostly working to make rent and it puts a lot of stress on my schoolwork and work balance because I need to work a lot more than I would if I took a part time job at a private company. I did a lot of job hopping to get to my current positions and it's not very easy to find jobs on campus because they aren't posted very well. You have to be on top of it to find jobs on campus.

job_title: Business Manager in College Park, MD
pros: The leave and benefits packages are really great. All federal holidays are worked, but those earned holidays allow us paid leave during winter break, which I imagine is really great for folks with families.
cons: Parking for staff is really expensive. It is more likely that you will move to a new job across campus than get a raise or promotion in your current department. The university makes promotion REALLY difficult for staff. Your in-office experience will really depend on your direct departmental culture and supervisor. There seems to be blatant disregard for employee concerns coming from the highest level of administration.
